prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The proposed observations will use the resolution and sensitivity of Cycle 2 ALMA to conduct a robust probe of gas density on the scales of individual clumps (1", or 0.04 pc) via simultaneous excitation analyses of multiple tracers and the inclusion of radiative excitation, yielding the authoritative values for the CND mass and density.
In order to meet these goals (constraining the radiative excitation of molecules in the CND and measuring its density and mass) we have chosen the following observing parameters:
Frequencies: Band 3 -- Two independent frequency settings are required at 3mm to cover the both the main lines and isotopologues of the primary molecular species for the density analysis (HNC, HCN, and HCO+), as well as to cover CH3CN, which will be used as a thermometer. Band 6 -- Two independent frequency settings are required at 1mm to cover the main lines and 13C isotopologues of HCN, HCO+, and HNC. In addition to these lines, the chosen frequency setups (all using the widest bandwidth available-- 1875 MHz) will yield a large number of transitions of CS, HC3N, SiO, SO, and four recombination lines, all of which will be used to more accurately determine the physical conditions in the molecular and ionized gas.
The spectral resolutions of 1 - 3 km/s for these wide-bandwidth settings is more than sufficient to resolve the 20-30 km/s linewidths of CND lines, and is necessary in order to disentangle several regions of the CND where there are multiple features along the same line of sight.
Sensitivity: We are requesting a sensitivity of 10 mJy per channel. In Bands 3 (6), this is equivalent to an RMS brightness temperature of ~1.5K (0.2K) per channel.
In Band 3, our sensitivity requirements are driven by the need to map CH3CN to derive temperatures, and to map the 13C isotopologues in order to accurately constrain line optical depths. We predict (based on a 30” resolution line survey of the CND at 3mm with IRAM) that for a ~2'' source size, the chosen sensitivity will be sufficient to map CH3CN, H13CN, HNC, HN13C, H13CO+ and 13CS (as well as CS, SO, SiO, HC3N, HNC, HCN, HCO+) with a peak signal to noise of at least 10 (up to 200). By integrating over the ~20-30 km/s linewidths of individual features we will further be able to detect rarer isotopologues (including HC15N, 34SO, and 29SiO) with a S/N of at least 10.
In Band 6, our sensitivity requirements are additionally driven by the need to map the faint v2=1 excited lines of HCN, HCO+, and HNC in order to constrain the radiative excitation of these species. We predict (based on a 30" resolution line survey of the CND at 1mm with APEX) that for a ~2'' source size, this sensitivity will be sufficient to map HCN v2=1 with a peak S/N of 50 and to map the v2=1 lines of HCO+ and HNC (if present) with a peak signal to noise of at least 10. Other species will be mapped wth S/N of tens to thousands, yielding extremely sensitive detections of any molecular gas interior to the CND, allowing the mass infall rate to be measured extremely accurately.
Area Mapped: The proposed observations will map the entire CND, including the interior ionized gas (a field of ~ 75'' by 90'' centered approximately on the central supermassive black hole Sgr A*). In Band 3a, this will require 7 pointings of the 12m array. In Band 3b this will require 11x 12m pointings. Each band 6 configuration will require 68x 12m pointings. For all bands, we ask for complementary ACA observations in order to recover extended emission up to the scale of the entire mapped region, as measuring the total mass in the CND relies on recovering the total flux present. Comparison of existing single-dish and SMA observations of HCN in the CND demonstrates that the contribution from extended emission in this region is significant: up to 50% of the total emission. These observations will require 3.8 hours with the 12m array, as well as 13.4 hours with the ACA.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The innermost concentration of molecular gas in our Galaxy is the Circumnuclear Disk (CND), a ring of gas and dust at a radius of ~1.5 pc from the central supermassive black hole. Depending upon the mass of this gas reservoir, the fate of the CND (whether it will it form stars, or eventually accrete on the black hole) will have a substantial impact on the evolution of the central parsec of our Galaxy. Its fate depends upon its density: gas clumps with densities > 10^7 cm^-3 are stable, and can collapse and form stars, whereas unstable clumps should quickly be sheared apart and eventually accrete onto the black hole. We propose to use the resolution and sensitivity of Cycle 2 ALMA to conduct a robust probe of gas density on the scales of individual clumps (1", or 0.04 pc) via simultaneous excitation analyses of multiple tracers and the inclusion of radiative excitation. Ultimately, this study will yield the authoritative values for the CND mass and density, quantities which vary in recent literature by 3-4 orders of magnitude, and will indicate the amount of gas present in the central parsecs, and whether it will feed the central black hole or contribute to a nuclear starburst.
